⁴ The oblatio (or ‘offering') was a ceremony which had to be performed by malefactore, or political offenders after condemna· tion, as a condition of pardon. If a malefactor, he was conducted from the prison where he had been confined, clothed in sack—cloth, with a mitre on his head, and a candle in his hand, to the Baptistery of San Giovanffi, where he was solemnly offered by an approved sponsor at the altar to God and to the Baptist. An individual who had been condemned for a political offanae, if not actually a prisoner, was obliged to constitute himself one technically by crossing the threshold of a prison, whence he was conducted to the Baptistery3 but the wearing a mitre and other degrading conditione were usually dispensed with in such a case. cf. the ’ following extract from the Provvisione of June 2, 1316: ‘possint eisque liceat intrari in carceribus Stincharum seu Vollognani aut in quocumque alio carcere dicti Comunis Florentio, et postquam fuerint in claustro seu intra muros circumdantes aliquem ipsorum carcerum, non obstante eo quod ipsi non scribantur per notarium
